history.content:
If you assume that the other player plays optimally as well, picking either 6 or 8, it's some fairly simple casework.

As I noted below, you have to make some assumption about how the opponent is playing to do any analysis. For example, if the opponent always picks 2, then 7 isn't optimal; 3 is.
If you assume that the other player plays optimally as well, picking either 6 or 8, it's some fairly simple casework.

children.subject:
Let's say that we have chosen 7 and the opponent chooses 6. When opponent chooses 8, argument below applies by symmetry. Opponent has no incentive to choose anything else. 

We win on 7,8,9,10,11,12 and lose otherwise.
The probability of rolling 7 is 1/6. The other two possibility ranges (2-6 vs. 8-12) are symmetrical, each with a probability of (1-1/6)/2 = 5/12.
Thus, our probability of winning is 1/6 + 5/12 = 7/12.

You can't make any comment about the probability of winning if you don't have a theory of how the opponent is playing. You have to make some assumption, whether it's optimal or uniformly random or otherwise.
Honestly, anon, it's not really possible to give crash courses in subjects that occupy whole semesters (*coughs* CS 70)
...to be fair, CS70 spends like a week on basic probability.

I don't get the Student Response.

1. First of all, how can you assume the other player plays optimally? It seems more like the other player is randomly choosing valid numbers.

2. Also, even if he always chooses 6 or 8, how do you find the chance that you win?

history.content:
I researched some past questions from a company I'll interview at.

You have 2 fairly weighted dice. You and an opponent pick any integer one after the other. If your number is closer to the sum of the faces on the rolled dice, you win. Do you want to go first and what number do you choose? What's the probability of winning?

My Answer

E[sum] = 3.5 + 3.5 = 7 (uniform distribution)

Go first so opponent doesn't choose 7. Choose 7. 

I don't know how compute my probability of winning though. Can someone help?

Also, I know this is off-topic and I apologize. I figured people here (including some of the top TAs in the world like Steven Bi) could solve this in seconds.
history.subject: [Probability] Interview question
